messageBody:
Dear All

I am new to this mailing list, so if my question is answered in the archives
somewhere, point me to them. [It's not answered in the FAQ nor in the cook
book etc.] I've been using JUnit (and TDD) for a fair while now, but I have a
problem that I'm about 90% sure is mere blindness on my part, but perhaps
not.

We have an interface (Graph) with multiple implementations (A and B). [Some
names have been changed to avoid complications.] I have a test case
AbstractTestGraph with an abstract method Graph getGraph(), where the
tests test the Graph(s) that getGraph() returns, and TestA/TestB define
getGraph() to return instances of A/B as appropriate. So far, so good, and
just as suggested in one of the Junit documents. The code for each test
case is nice and short.

Well ... I lied about A and B; it's more like A, B, C, and X. And likely to
be more, since Y and Z exist but may not be properly included in the
test suite at the moment.

(1) How can I write a test generator which takes A.class, X.class etc as
arguments and constructs the necessary suite? The obvious-to-me code

public static TestCase makeMyTest( final Class someGraph )
{
class TestSomeGraph extends AbstractTestGraph
{
public TestSomeGraph( String name ) { super( name ); }
public static TestSuite suite() { return new TestSuite(
TestSomeGraph ); }
public Graph getGraph()
{ return someGraph.getConstructor( new Class[] {}
).newInstance( new Object [] {} ); }
}
}

doesn't work, because TestSomeGraph isn't public, so junit can't reflect to
it.
And Java, bless it's cotton socks, has a hissy fit if you try and make the
nested
class public.

And there's more. Different instances of Graph have differing capabilities, eg
some of them are read-only, some of them handle transactions, etc. I'd
like the test generator to only add those tests that are relevant given the
appropriate capabilities. My plan was to arrange that makeMyTest would
look at the current capabilities [which would be set up per-class] and replace
`suite` with something that added in just those tests that were needed
(refactoring AbstractTestGraph into the subgroups). Since makeMyTest
doesn't work, I can't do that either ...

So ... am I dead-ended in the wrong alley? Missing something obvious?
Missing something subtle? Any advice would be welcome. If I have to
hack junit source code I will, but I feel that surely I don't need to ...

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
